title: How Often Should You Wash Short Hair? Tips for Keeping Your Hair Healthy and Clean

steps.title: This depends on your lifestyle and the products you use.
steps.content: This depends on your lifestyle and the products you use. Your scalp produces an oil called sebum. Since your hair's short, that sebum can make your hair look oily pretty quickly. Shampooing your hair every day, though, might end up stripping the oil from your scalp. This can dry it out. You might try shampooing your hair every other day to retain moisture and prevent this from happening. [1] X Research source Shampooing your hair every other day won't be too harsh on your hair, especially if there's a lot of oil buildup on your scalp and in your hair. If you have curly hair and frequently use a lot of products to style it, you may want to shampoo it more frequently.

steps.title: Shampoo your hair just once or twice a week if it's curly or thick.
steps.content: Shampoo your hair just once or twice a week if it's curly or thick. It takes oil from your scalp a lot longer to travel down the length of curly hair so you don't need to shampoo it very often. If you do shampoo your hair frequently, it can really dry out your curls or waves. [2] X Research source You'll find that by limiting how often you shampoo, your curls will be less frizzy and dry.

steps.title: Shampoo your hair about every other day if it's straight.
steps.content: Shampoo your hair about every other day if it's straight. Since oil can move down the length of your hair faster than curly hair, your straight hair will look oilier. This just means that you should shampoo it more frequently. [3] X Research source Since you have short hair, too, your straight hair will probably look oily after a few days of not shampooing it. You may want to use dry shampoo on the days that you don't shampoo.

steps.title: Shampoo your hair every other day if you have fine hair.
steps.content: Shampoo your hair every other day if you have fine hair. If your hair feels thin or doesn't have a lot of volume, you'll see oil build up pretty quickly. Plan on shampooing your hair every other day. [4] X Research source You should also limit how many hair products you use since these can build up in your hair.

steps.title: Shampoo once or twice a week if your scalp is dry.
steps.content: Shampoo once or twice a week if your scalp is dry. If you're noticing that your scalp is dry or itchy, this means there's not enough oil and you don't need to shampoo as frequently. [5] X Research source If you've got chemically-treated hair (colored, permed, or relaxed), it's probably a little dry, so try shampooing it less often.

steps.title: Shampoo your hair more frequently if you've got an oily scalp.
steps.content: Shampoo your hair more frequently if you've got an oily scalp. Try shampooing your hair a day earlier than you usually do to remove some of this oil. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source If you notice flaky white dandruff, pick up a shampoo designed for treating dandruff and massage it directly onto your scalp at least 1 or 2 times a week. Exfoliating any dry patches can also help remove excess dandruff and dry skin from your hair. Exfoliate by using a comb with rounded teeth prior to shampooing.

steps.title: Use a shampoo that's formulated for your hair type.
steps.content: Use a shampoo that's formulated for your hair type. Read shampoo labels to find a product that's designed for your hair texture and condition. [7] X Expert Source Shun Pittman Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 14 April 2021. That's really the most important part of shampooing short hair . Get your hair wet with warm water and squirt a coin-sized amount of shampoo into your palms. Massage the shampoo onto your scalp and through your hair. Then, thoroughly rinse it out with warm water. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source For example, if you've got oily hair, reach for a purifying shampoo rather than a moisturizing or conditioning product. If you have coarse or dry hair, go for a hydrating, moisturizing shampoo. If you've got fine hair, look for a gentle shampoo that won't leave a lot of product to weigh down your hair. If you get your hair colored, choose a shampoo and conditioner specifically for color-treated hair since it prevents product buildup without making your color turn dull. If you have natural or curly hair, your hair is probably pretty dry so choose a moisturizing or hydrating shampoo.

steps.title: Yes—conditioner protects your hair from damage.
steps.content: Yes—conditioner protects your hair from damage. It also keeps it from drying out since you've washed a lot of the natural oil out of your hair. Choose a conditioner designed for your hair type and massage it through the ends of your hair, not your scalp. [9] X Expert Source Shun Pittman Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 14 April 2021. Let the conditioner sit on your hair for about 5 minutes—or whatever is recommended on the label—so it really penetrates and conditions. Then, rinse it off with cool water. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source If you've got super short hair and you're concerned regular conditioner will be too heavy, it's completely fine to use a lightweight leave-in conditioner instead.

steps.title: Not necessarily.
steps.content: Not necessarily. If your scalp makes a lot of oil, your hair is thin or fine, or it's not healthy, then your hair will probably look oily faster regardless of the length. [11] X Research source You might find that it's easier to hide oily hair if it's long. For instance, you could pull it back into a sleek ponytail or tuck it under a stylish headband. Using a lot of products will increase how quickly your hair starts to appear oily. You'll likely have to shampoo it again sooner in this case.
